titleInfo.title: Structural and Biochemical Characterization of Guanylate Binding Protein 2

mods:mods.abstract: Pathogenic microorganisms gain entry inside the host cell by breaching anatomical barriers andinvading tissues. The host cell in turn depends on the sentinels of cell autonomous defense system to fight off the invading pathogen. This cell autonomous defense has a broad spectrum of microbial sensitivity and in addition maintains the signals for cellular homeostasis for the key housekeeping functions. The key players of the cell autonomous immunity belong to the family of interferon stimulated genes (ISGs). The ISGs can directly counteract the pathogenic microorganism, or they can act as immune editors to influence the other immune effectors. Prominent within the thousands of ISGs overexpressed during infection is a family of GTPases. Guanylate binding proteins (GBPs) are one of the four members of the interferon stimulated GTPase family and act as a major hub of defensive responses against a diverse array of pathogens. The myriad of roles played by GBPs in mediating host defense against bacterial, viral and protozoan pathogens has been established over the past 20 years. Recently, structural and biochemical studies are playing a key role in elucidating the molecular mechanism of the robust immunity mediated by GBPs. Such studies carried out on GBP1 in the past have proved that this family resembles the dynamin superfamily. GBP2 is one of the two highly inducible GBPs, yet little is known about the activation and regulation of GBP2. In our study, we characterized the GTPase domain of GBP2 both structurally and biochemically. By determining the crystal structures of the GBP2 G domain in the different nucleotide-bound states, we unveiled distinct conformational states adopted by the nucleotide-binding pocket and the distal regions of the protein in the course of GTP hydrolysis. The conformational changes in the G domain are further transmitted to the C-terminal helical domain as is evident from the comparative analysis of the nucleotide-free full-length GBP2. We also identified subtle differences in the G domain induced by different nucleotides that provide insights into the molecular basis of monomer-dimer transition and enzymatic activity. By employing biochemistry and small angle X-ray scattering, we have deciphered that the second to last alpha helix at the C-terminal end of GBP2 plays a role in regulating the activation of the protein. These findings pave the way for future investigations aimed at elucidating the precise molecular mechanisms underlying GBP2's role in the immune response and may facilitate the development of targeted therapeutic strategies against intracellular pathogens.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Qian Yin, Professor Directing Dissertation; Zucai Suo, University Representative; Hengli Tang, Committee Member; Margaret Elizabeth Stroupe, Committee Member; Jonathan Hancock Dennis, Committee Member.
